newsitem.title: UK: Kenya sugar industry self-sufficient from 2000 - KSA.
newsitem.headline: Kenya sugar industry self-sufficient from 2000 - KSA.

text.p: Kenya's sugar industry should be self-sufficient from the start of next century due to improved cane supply and a programme of factory expansions, the chief executive of the Kenya Sugar Authority (KSA) said on Tuesday. "The short and medium term prospects of the sugar industry are promising," said Francis Chahonyo in a speech prepared for a two-day conference hosted by the London-based International Sugar Organization (ISO).
"It is forecast that the local sugar industry will be able to rise to its expectations for the country to achieve a sustainable self-sufficiency in sugar production from the year 2000," he said.

Kenya has been a net importer of sugar since 1984. It took in 24,440 tonnes in 1994, sharply down from the 174,049 tonnes the previous year. Sugar consumption has been stable at 560,000 tonnes for the past three years although production has fluctuated, Chahonyo said.
A package of government measures to boost the local sugar industry had yielded positive results, he said.
These included a 1992 levy giving credit for cane development, purchase of farm machinery and factory maintenance. The deregulation of price controls and marketing liberalisation had also helped.
In June, the Kenyan government raised ad valorem tax on imported sugar to 35 percent from 15 percent to discourage cheap imports and boost domestic production.

Kenya's area under sugar cane increased by an average 9.3 percent each year from 1992 to 1995, and cane yields had also risen, Chahonyo said. "The improved cane supply has prompted various sugar companies to embark upon rehabilitation and/or expansion programmes for their factories," he said.
The Kenyan government has a controlling stake in five out of seven factories operating in the country, and these five mills account for over 95 percent of total sugar production.
